posts.name: James
posts.cooked:
Our team has a general blueprint of how to drive to a specific pole on the reef to score and we would like some feedback.

Our idea is to use our robot’s odometry from the swerve, along with vision, to update our robot’s pose. Then, our codriver has 2 buttons that represent left or right (robot-oriented). If our camera sees a reef AprilTag and the co-driver presses the left or right button. The robot would rotate facing the reef while translating to the left or right of the AprilTag, lining up with one of the poles.

What libraries would I use to accomplish this? We are new to 3d AprilTag tracking and are using YAGSL . Should we use PathPlanner on the fly path generation? Is it something easier than that? It’s tricky because we want a high degree of precision and accuracy. I would love to hear all of your thoughts!

posts.name: Elijah Beard
posts.cooked: Somebody might have a better idea than me but I will bite. The sides’ angle will be constant so you can make a HashMap that correlates an apriltag ID with a robot yaw. Then, you can move the robot’s x-axis (robot-centric) using the x position from the camera as an input (edit: with PID should have mentioned that). For the y-axis, you might want your driver to handle that but you could also calculate the distance from the April tag and control the y-axis based on that (robot-centric). This is pretty much your idea, you would use standard drive functions but change the inputs of the standard drive function. This is a basic approach and it does not use botposes. Pathplanner on-the-fly generation might work just as well but it could also be less accurate. I would try the path planner approach to see if it is accurate enough and if not you could implement the more basic approach. You could also use them together as well.

posts.name: Ethan Grieshop
posts.cooked:
What kind of camera are you using? If you have limelights, I’d highly recommend using the LimelightLib software, as it gives you good out of the box performance as well as room for optimizations.

If you’re using a different type of camera, the standard is to use photonvision I believe.

posts.name: Ethan Grieshop
posts.cooked: Also, I forgot to mention this, but pid can be your best friend here. It’s very easy to set up a pid controller for your x position, y position, and rotation that takes care of all the movement for you, and you’ll be able to easily correct based on any vision measurements you receive.

posts.name: James
posts.cooked: Our team uses PhotonVision with an Orange Pi5  and 2 OV9281 cameras. We will have one on each side of the robot. One facing towards the reef and another facing the opposite direction. YAGSL seems to have strong camera integration, I’m just unsure of the repeatability.

posts.name: James
posts.cooked: I know how to use PID controllers for this, I’m just trying to findd the most effective way. I though pose would be the best because we may lose sight of the reef when moving close up to it

posts.name: Ari Davidson
posts.cooked: Last year we used a PID loop combined with our odometry(we use vision to help update our odometry) to align with the amp. here is the link to our code if you’re curious

posts.name: Ethan Grieshop
posts.cooked: You’ll want to keep the reef in your sights for as long as possible for sure. Also, if you dig deep enough into pathplanner, it’s basically just a profiled pid controller making you follow a trajectory. Since you’re only going to the nearest tag, you shouldn’t ever really have to go around anything, so it’s best to take a straight shot to the reef, which is exactly what a pid controller will do for you. I also agree with the other commenter: having some kind of map of reef poses is super helpful for accomplishing this.
With PV its a few lines to change

posts.name: James
posts.cooked: How can I drive to a specific pose with YAGSL ?

posts.name: James
posts.cooked: I’m having trouble using this right now and I’m trying to debug my camera setup. How can I pull the estimated camera pose x,y, and rotation relative to the apriltag as doubles so I can put them to smart dashboard?

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: We put the Pose2d or Pose3d out to NT so we can view them with AdvantageScope.

posts.name: Justin Buist
posts.cooked:
I’m going to suggest using AdvantageScope and Pose objects for this one too. Publish out:

Where your robot thinks it is (robot pose)

Where your vision poses are (helpful to know)

Where you’re trying to drive to (much nicer to find out your math is wrong by seeing the target in the wrong spot vs letting the robot fly in the wrong direction)

Looks something like this:

Screenshot_20250219_105246 1001×886 127 KB

Screenshot_20250219_105246 1001×886 127 KB

Screenshot_20250219_105246 1001×886 127 KB

One thing we cooked up for drivers this year is they smack the left or right bumpers and the robot:

Figures out the nearest Reef AprilTag ID. Just loop through the list of valid Reef tag’s, find which one is closest to the robot pose. Use the Tag’s Pose object to translate left/right by your desired offset. You don’t actually have to dig into trig to do this; the tag’s have proper rotation settings in their Pose objects, so you end up with something like: left_pose  = tag_pose.transformBy( Transform2d(Translation2d(0, 0.165), Rotation2d.fromDegrees(180) )

(Python example, sorry)

That creates a pose that’s just a bit left (or maybe right, reverse the sign on 0.165 if I got it backwards) and rotated 180 degrees. The tag “faces” outward from the reef and you want your robot pose, probably, facing into the reef. Unless you back into it, then set the rotation to 0 instead of 180.

Pop that into YAGSL ’s Drive to Pose and watch it boogie!

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
Here’s the minimum code to post a Pose3d to NT for AS.

Also, I think AS has comet tails on the robot path in Field2d so if you like those, you can use whatever type needed to display there - not sure if it’s Pose2d, Pose3d, or Field2d or any of those.
